children.name: all of a group of things or people
all
children.definition: /ɔːl/  all the things or people in a group:
examples: ▪ There was no one in the office -- they were all having lunch.
▪ The new government has banned all political parties.

children.name: we/you/them etc all
examples: ▪ He thanked us all for coming.
▪ I’ve read five of his books, and I’m not going to stop until I’ve read them all.

children.name: all the/these/their/my etc
examples: ▪ Did you take all these pictures yourself?
▪ All his clothes were spread around the room.
▪ All the teachers in my school are women.

children.name: all of
examples: ▪ I’ve used up all of my traveler’s checks.
▪ She invited all of her friends to the party.

children.name: almost/nearly all
examples: ▪ The Prime Minister’s plan would cut almost all subsidies to state-run industries.
▪ Nearly all news organizations have refused to broadcast the victim’s name during the trial.

children.name: all dogs/cars/children etcuse this to make a general statement about things or people of the same kind
examples: ▪ All mammals are warm-blooded.
▪ All cars over 5 years old must have a test certificate.

children.name: everything
children.definition: /ˈevriθɪŋ/  all the things in a group, or all the things that someone says or does:
examples: ▪ The customs officer asked us to take everything out of our suitcases.
▪ Don’t believe everything you read in the newspapers.
▪ Everything in the store costs less than $10.

children.name: everything elseall other things
examples: ▪ I have a tent and a sleeping-bag, and Ben said he’d lend me everything else I need for the camping trip.

children.name: everyone/everybody
children.definition: /ˈevriwʌn, ˈevribɒdiǁ-bɑːdi/  all people or all the people in a particular group:
examples: ▪ I think everyone enjoyed the party.
▪ If everybody is ready, I’ll begin.
▪ Why is everyone so excited about this tax cut?

children.name: the lot
children.definition: /ðə ˈlɒtǁ-ˈlɑːt/  Britishinformalall the things in a group or set, considered together:

children.name: tất cả
examples: ▪ I left my purse with my cheque book and car keys on the kitchen table and thieves broke in and stole the lot.
▪ Janine bought four cream cakes, but her friends didn’t turn up for dinner so she ate the lot herself.

children.name: every
children.definition: /ˈevri/  all -- used only withsingularnouns:
examples: ▪ Every room in the house was painted white.
▪ She bought presents for every member of her family.

children.name: every singleuse this to emphasize that you really mean everyone or everything, especially when this is surprising
examples: ▪ It rained every single day of our vacation.

children.name: every single one/every last one
examples: ▪ The police questioned every single one of the passengers on the plane.

children.name: each
children.definition: /iːtʃ/  all -- use this to emphasize that you meaneveryseparateperson or thing in a group:
examples: ▪ She had a ring on each finger of her right hand.
▪ They read through each job application very carefully.
▪ The president shook hands with each member of the team.

children.name: each of
examples: ▪ We will consider each of these questions in turn.
▪ She gave each of them a plate of food.

children.name: each one
examples: ▪ George and Elizabeth had visited 15 apartments and had found something wrong with each one.

children.name: in/for/to etc each
examples: ▪ She dug several tiny holes in the soil, planting a seed in each.

children.name: we/they/us etc each
examples: ▪ My brother and I each have our own room.
▪ She gave us each a pen and a piece of paper.

children.name: without exception
children.definition: /wɪðˌaʊt ɪkˈsepʃən/ formaluse this to say that something is true of every single one of the people or things in a large group:

children.name: mà ko có ngoại lệ
examples: ▪ Every department in this city, without exception, has experienced cutbacks.

children.name: almost without exception
examples: ▪ Economists agreed on the President’s proposal, almost without exception.

children.name: the works
children.definition: /ðə ˈwɜʳks/spokeninformaleverything in a group of similar things or all the things that are needed for a particular activity:
examples: mọi thứ, mọi truyện
▪ ‘What would you like on your hotdog -- mustard, ketchup, relish?’ ‘Give me the works.’
▪ The school needs new computers, calculators, chairs, cooking utensils...basically, the works.

children.name: the whole enchilada
children.definition: /shebangalsothe whole nine yards/ðə ˌhəʊl ˌentʃˈlɑːdə, ʃˈbæŋ, ðə ˌhəʊl naɪn ˈjɑːʳdz/ Americanspokeninformaleverything that you could possibly want, or expect to have:

children.name: tất tần tật
examples: ▪ He bought the computer, the printer, and the modem - the whole shebang.
▪ It sounds like a great job offer -- benefits, retirement, the whole enchilada.
▪ The guy in immigration wanted to see the whole nine yards -- passport, birth certificate, driver’s license.

children.name: affecting or including all of st
total/complete
children.definition: /ˈtəʊtl, kəmˈplɪːt/ affectingeverything or every part of a situation:

children.name: hoàn toàn
examples: ▪ They want a total ban on cigarette advertising.
▪ My parents had complete control over my life.
▪ The satellite TV station is providing total coverage of the Olympic Games.

children.name: blanket
children.definition: /ˈblæŋkɪt, ˈblæŋkət/  blanketdecision/statement/term etcone thataffectsevery part of a situation:

children.name: bao trùm, bao phủ
examples: ▪ A blanket requirement was announced by education officials -- all schools had to cut their budgets by 25%.
▪ Dementia is a blanket term for various types of psychiatric disorder.

children.name: overall
children.definition: /ˈəʊvərɔːl/  including or involving all or almost all the parts of asituation:
examples: overall/ˌəʊvərˈɔːl/ [adverb]
▪ One or two products didn’t do so well, but overall we’ve had a highly successful year.

children.name: toàn bộ, toàn diện, toàn thể
examples: ▪ Even though some of the details are badly done, the overall effect of the painting is very dramatic.
▪ His attitude towards his job seemed consistent with his overall approach to life.
▪ Conference members agreed on an overall approach to drug abuse that focuses on prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation.

children.name: global
children.definition: /ˈgləʊbəl/  involving all possible parts of anideaorsystem:

children.name: toàn bộ, toàn thể
examples: ▪ We’ve done a global study on the company’s weaknesses.
▪ Simon & Schuster said it no longer wanted the smaller company because it did not fit into its global strategy.

children.name: all-embracing
children.definition: /ˌɔːl ɪmˈbreɪsɪŋ◂/  all-embracingconcept/statement/term etcone in which all features of a situation have beenthoughtof andincluded:

children.name: bao gồm tất cả
examples: ▪ The prison governor now has all-embracing powers to deal with any situation in the way he thinks fit.
▪ Physicists are searching for one all-embracing theory that covers matter, energy, radiation, and gravity.

children.name: what you say to talk about two people or things
both
children.definition: /bəʊθ/  use this to talk about two people or things together:
examples: ▪ Paul and I are both scared of spiders.
▪ I can’t decide which dress to buy. I like them both.
▪ Both drivers were injured, but not seriously.

children.name: both the/these/my etc
examples: ▪ Both the robbers were wearing masks.
▪ Both their parents are doctors.

children.name: both of
examples: ▪ Both of us felt a little sick after dinner.
▪ Both of the windows had been broken.

children.name: the two of them/us/you
children.definition: /ðə ˈtuː əv ðəm, ʌs, juː/  spoken both the people that you are talking about:
examples: ▪ While the two of them talked about cars, I went into the kitchen to make coffee.
▪ We’re taking a romantic vacation - just the two of us.
▪ I want the money to be shared equally between the two of you.

children.name: the pair of them/us/you
children.definition: /ðə ˈpeəʳ əv ðəm, ʌs, juː/  British spoken both the people that you are talking about - used especially when you are angry or disappointed with them:
examples: ▪ Get out of here, the pair of you!
▪ There we were, stranded in the middle of nowhere with no money between the pair of us.

children.name: each
children.definition: /iːtʃ/  use this to talk about two people or things when you think of them as separate:
examples: ▪ My wife and I each have our own bank account.

children.name: each of
examples: ▪ Each of the teams has already won two games.

children.name: each other/one another
children.definition: /iːtʃ ˈʌðəʳ, wʌn əˈnʌðəʳ/  use this to say that each of two people does the same thing to the other, or has the same feeling about the other:
examples: ▪ My boyfriend and I don’t talk to each other very much anymore.
▪ The twins looked at one another and giggled.

children.name: each other’s/one another’s
examples: ▪ Ron and Joe didn’t like each other’s girlfriends.

children.name: either
children.definition: /ˈaɪðəʳǁˈiː-/  use this to talk about one of two people, places, or things, especially when it does not matter which one: ▪ ‘Would you like tea or coffee?’ ‘Either - I don’t mind.’▪ You can operate the controls with either hand.either of▪ If you see either of these men, contact the police immediately.▪ She says she never met either of them before.either somebody/something or somebody/something▪ I usually drink either coke or beer with pizza.

children.name: neither
children.definition: /ˈnaɪðəʳǁˈniː-/  not one or the other of two people, places, or things etc: ▪ ‘Do you want milk or lemon in your tea?’ ‘Neither, thanks.’▪ The game wasn’t very exciting, and neither team played well.neither of▪ Luckily, neither of the passengers was hurt in the crash.neither somebody/something nor somebody/something▪ Neither her mother nor her father knew about her boyfriend.

children.name: mutual
children.definition: /ˈmjuːtʃuəl/  mutual feelings/friends/interest etc mutual feelings etc are ones that both people have at the same time: ▪ The couple were introduced to each other by a mutual friend.▪ An investment in my company would be to our mutual benefit.▪ They would meet every week to discuss matters of mutual interest.

children.name: share
children.definition: /ʃeəʳ/  to both have the same opinion, attitude, interest etc: ▪ They share an interest in 16th century architecture.▪ My husband and my mother share the same birthday.

children.name: all
children.definition: /ɔːl/  all of something -- used especially withuncountablenouns:

children.name: all the/this/that/my etc
examples: ▪ He spends all his money on beer and cigarettes.
▪ I’ve seen all her movies.
▪ Did you eat all that bread?

children.name: all of the/this/that/my etc
examples: ▪ I enjoyed the book although I didn’t understand all of it.

children.name: it all
examples: ▪ Where’s my change? You didn’t spend it all, did you?

children.name: all day/week/year etcthe whole of a period of time
examples: ▪ I spent all day cleaning the house.

children.name: whole
children.definition: /həʊl/  all of something that islarge, long, or has a lot of parts,for example a large area of land, a long period of time, or a large group of people:
examples: ▪ I didn’t see her again for a whole year.
▪ ‘I want the whole area searched!’ said the chief of police.
▪ She was so frightened, her whole body was shaking.
▪ Nora had spent her whole life trying to find happiness.

children.name: the whole of somethingall of a particular thing, time, or place
examples: ▪ She spent the whole of the journey complaining about her boyfriend.
▪ The Romans conquered almost the whole of Western Europe.

children.name: entire
children.definition: /ɪnˈtaɪəʳ/  all of something -- use this especially to show that you are annoyed or surprised by this:

children.name: toàn bộ, tất cả
examples: ▪ I wasted an entire day waiting at the airport.
▪ We realized that our entire conversation had been recorded.
▪ This function of the word processor allows you to correct the entire document before printing.

children.name: every (last) inch
children.definition: every (last) bit/inch/ounce/drop/ˌevri (lɑːstǁlæst) ˈbɪt, ˈɪntʃ, ˈaʊns, ˈdrɒpǁˈdrɑːp/  the whole of something -- use this to emphasize that someoneusesall of something, or that somethingcoversall of an area:
examples: ▪ Every inch of my niece’s wall is covered with posters of pop groups.
▪ We had to use every last bit of our savings.
▪ I watched him drain every last drop out of the bottle.

children.name: from start to finish
children.definition: /frəm ˌstɑːʳt tə ˈfɪnɪʃ/  including all of something such as an event, process, or piece of writing: từ đầu đến cuối
examples: ▪ I’ve read the book three times from start to finish.
▪ The whole case was badly handled from start to finish.

children.name: lock, stock, and barrel
children.definition: /ˌlɒk stɒk ənd ˈbærəlǁˌlɑːk stɑːk-/spokenincluding every part of something -- use this aboutsomeonemoving, buying or selling all of something:

children.name: toàn bộ
examples: ▪ He moved the whole company, lock, stock, and barrel, to Mexico.
▪ The Knolls have owned the town lock, stock, and barrel for 15 years.
